docTitle.titlePart:
Monolithic columns for fast high-performance liquid
chromatography separations

byline.affiliation:
Centro para la Calidad de los Alimentos, Instituto Nacional de Investigación y Tecnología Agraria y
Alimentaria (INIA)

front.div:
High-Performance Liquid Chromatography is a powerful analytical tool that has been extensively used for
the analysis of wide range of compounds from different food matrices. The heart of each HPLC method
is the column, which enables separation of compounds based upon selectivity and column performance.
At the present time, most common HPLC columns are packed with 3-5 µm porous silica microparticles.
The separation performance is mainly determined by the particle size and distribution and the quality of
the packing of the particles within the column. The current trend for the analysis of compounds in foods by
HPLC is toward fast, high sensitivity and high resolution separations using newly developed materials and
equipment.
HPLC column technology has seen considerable improvement in the last decade. Fast HPLC for
traditional, particle based columns usually includes higher flow rates (limited by pressure), increased
column temperature, smaller particle diameter and shorter column length. To maintain efficiency with
shorter columns, smaller particle size is necessary. Columns packed with very small particles (less than 2
µm particle size) can shorten analysis times while maintaining, or even increasing, separation
efficiencies. Unfortunately the use of small particle columns reaches the pressure capacity of
"conventional" HPLC systems using 3-5 µm particles limiting both column length and flow rates.
In order to overcome the pressure limitations of conventional chromatographic systems (of approximately
400 bar), new systems capable of withstanding higher pressures (800-1000 bar) were developed with the
aim of exploring the ever decreasing particle size of columns and their potential to deliver higher
efficiency and faster chromatographic analyses.
